title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate BetterCook’s total revenue at the allocatively efficient quantity as $4,536 and/or does not show the work.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the quantity demanded will increase by less than 3% and/or does not explain that the demand is inelastic in this price range because marginal revenue is negative.
The response states that the quantity demanded will increase by less than 3% and explains that the demand is inelastic in this price range because marginal revenue is negative.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that at a quantity of 29 units BetterCook’s marginal product is decreasing and/or does not explain that the marginal cost is rising.
The response states that at a quantity of 29 units BetterCook’s marginal product is decreasing and explains that the marginal cost is rising.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the firm’s profit-maximizing quantity as 43 units and/or does not explain that at that quantity marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.
The response identifies that the firm’s profit-maximizing quantity as 43 units and explains that at that quantity marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the firm earns zero economic profit and/or does not explain that the firm’s average total cost curve is tangent to the demand curve, or the firm charges a price equal to the average total cost, or P = ATC = $98 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGqbGaaeiiai aab2dacaqGGaGaaeyqaiaabsfacaqGdbGaaeiiaiaab2dacaqGGaGa aeijaiaabMdacaqG4aaaaa@425C@ .

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that no, Scheff does not have a dominant strategy and/or does not explain that when BetterCook chooses to maintain its price, Scheff’s payoff is higher when it does not advertise ($250 > $150) MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGOaGaaeijai aabkdacaqG1aGaaeimaiaabccacaqG+aGaaeiiaiaabscacaqGXaGa aeynaiaabcdacaqGPaaaaa@41E9@ , and when BetterCook chooses to lower its price, Scheff’s payoff is higher when it advertises $650 > $450 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGKaGaaeOnai aabwdacaqGWaGaaeiiaiaab6dacaqGGaGaaeijaiaabsdacaqG1aGa aeimaaaa@4099@ ; therefore, Scheff does not have a dominant strategy.

The response states that no, Scheff does not have a dominant strategy and explains that when BetterCook chooses to maintain its price, Scheff’s payoff is higher when it does not advertise ($250 > $150) MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGOaGaaeijai aabkdacaqG1aGaaeimaiaabccacaqG+aGaaeiiaiaabscacaqGXaGa aeynaiaabcdacaqGPaaaaa@41E9@ , and when BetterCook chooses to lower its price, Scheff’s payoff is higher when it advertises $650 > $450 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGKaGaaeOnai aabwdacaqGWaGaaeiiaiaab6dacaqGGaGaaeijaiaabsdacaqG1aGa aeimaaaa@4099@ ; therefore, Scheff does not have a dominant strategy.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the Nash equilibrium as BetterCook maintains its price and Scheff does not advertise with payoffs of ($600, $250) MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGOaGaaeijai aabAdacaqGWaGaaeimaiaabYcacaqGGaGaaeijaiaabkdacaqG1aGa aeimaiaabMcaaaa@4134@ , and/or does not explain that if BetterCook chooses to lower its price, its payoff will decrease from $600 to $200 and if Scheff chooses to advertise, its payoff will decrease from $250 to $150; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

The response identifies the Nash equilibrium as BetterCook maintains its price and Scheff does not advertise with payoffs of ($600, $250) MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGOaGaaeijai aabAdacaqGWaGaaeimaiaabYcacaqGGaGaaeijaiaabkdacaqG1aGa aeimaiaabMcaaaa@4134@ , and explains that if BetterCook chooses to lower its price, its payoff will decrease from $600 to $200 and if Scheff chooses to advertise, its payoff will decrease from $250 to $150; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response states that no, this offer will not result in a Nash equilibrium with different strategies and explains that the Nash equilibrium strategies will still be for BetterCook to maintain its price and for Scheff to not advertise with payoffs of ($600, $250) because if BetterCook chooses to lower its price, its payoff will decrease from $600 to $250 ($200+$50) and if Scheff chooses to advertise its payoff will decrease from $250 to $150; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy. Or explains that with the offer BetterCook’s dominant strategy will continue to be to maintain the price because its payoff will always be higher ($400>$350 and $600>$250), and since Scheff has no dominant strategy, it is better off to not advertise ($250>$150); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

The response states that no, this offer will not result in a Nash equilibrium with different strategies and explains that the Nash equilibrium strategies will still be for BetterCook to maintain its price and for Scheff to not advertise with payoffs of ($600, $250) because if BetterCook chooses to lower its price, its payoff will decrease from $600 to $250 ($200+$50) and if Scheff chooses to advertise its payoff will decrease from $250 to $150; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy. Or explains that with the offer BetterCook’s dominant strategy will continue to be to maintain the price because its payoff will always be higher ($400>$350 and $600>$250), and since Scheff has no dominant strategy, it is better off to not advertise ($250>$150); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.
